Article.Naam: Wound bed preparation: assessment and management

Question.Question: 1: Wounds are considered to be poly-microbial and consequently require treatment with antimicrobials.
2: Use low-toxicity solutions, such as normal saline or water, when cleansing wounds.
3: Hydrogen peroxide can harm granulation tissue. May form emboli if used in deep sinuses.
4: Cetrimide is active against Gram-positive and Gram-negative bacteria with very little effect on tissue.
5: Film should not be used on draining or infected wounds.
6: Topical negative pressure therapy removes infectious material and/or fluids, from the wound bed.
7: Hydrocolloids may be used on fragile skin.
1: Alginates are primarily derived from seaweed.
2: Collagen dressings are indicated for the treatment of third-degree burns.
3: Foam dressings should not be used on dry wounds with eschar or wounds with little exudate.
4: Hydrocolloid dressings cannot be used on clinically infected wounds or wounds with heavy exudate.
6: Hydrogels should not be used on full-thickness ulcers, vascular or pressure ulcers.
7: Film dressings are contra-indicated in the treatment of third-degree burns.
